Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to understand how bacteria make a copy of their DNA. Accurate and efficient DNA replication is critical for the survival of all organisms. However, DNA replicates with occasional spontaneous errors, and in addition, it is constantly damaged by environmental factors. DNA replication enzymes (replicative DNA polymerases) are generally unable to copy damaged DNA; there are special DNA polymerases that are used by cells to copy across the DNA damage. This project studies the accessory proteins, single-stranded DNA binding protein and the beta processivity clamp, and asks how they regulate the activity of replicative and specialized DNA polymerases. Students trained as part of this project will be highly skilled in molecular biology, biotechnology, and biophysics and will be prepared to pursue further education and training, to pursue careers in basic research, or to contribute to the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries in the local area and beyond, thereby contributing to the life sciences industries. This project will also give high school students the opportunity to gain research experience. Furthermore, by integrating a research project in the Principles of Chemical Biology teaching laboratory, this project will expose more students to research.

Many key aspects of bacterial DNA replication remain poorly understood. The work proposed here will elucidate the factors that control DNA replication in the model bacterium E. coli and will determine how they exert their control. One focus of the project is on single-stranded DNA binding protein (SSB) as a regulator protein. SSB protects single-stranded DNA and is thought to eliminate DNA structures that can inhibit replication. SSB has been shown to inhibit polymerase activity of the pol III alpha subunit and core, of which alpha is a part, but enhance the activity of other DNA polymerases; the work in this proposal will determine the molecular basis for these differential effects. By analyzing the activity of DNA polymerases on undamaged and damaged DNA and with accessory proteins SSB and the beta processivity clamp, kinetic parameters of each polymerase will be determined to provide insights into the dynamic processes of proofreading and polymerase switching. This project combines biochemical, cellular, and biophysical single molecule methods to develop a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms of DNA replication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to probe the interactions and mechanisms of DNA replication proteins, which are responsible for accurately copying DNA for each cell division. The work focused on the E. coli DNA replication proteins single-stranded DNA binding protein (SSB), the polymerase responsible for carrying out the majority of DNA replication DNA pol III, and DNA damage-bypass polymerases DinB (pol IV) and pol V. These are important because every time a cell divides, its DNA must be replicated accurately in its entirety. DNA pol III is responsible for most of the DNA replication in bacterial cells and it possesses an efficient DNA polymerase that synthesizes DNA as well as a proofreader that corrects mistakes as needed. Force spectroscopy on single DNA molecules showed that both the synthesis and proofreading steps occur in bursts separated by pauses, rather than in a smooth reaction cycle. Initiation of the synthesis steps did not depend on force, but the proofreading reaction did depend on the force applied to the DNA. The force on DNA can separate the DNA strands, mimicking the effect of an incorrect base being incorporated. This work showed that a fluctuation equivalent to two base pairs opening is sufficient to trigger proofreading. It also showed that the synthesis and proofreading functions are independent, and that whether synthesis or proofreading activity predominates depends on the stability of DNA.

A major challenge to DNA replication is the high rate of DNA damage that occurs in all cells. The specialized DNA polymerases pol IV and pol V help cells tolerate this damage by copying DNA containing damage, but without correcting the damage. Their regulation is critical to cell survival because they are inherently error-prone and thus their access to DNA must be controlled in order to maintain the integrity of DNA. One focus of this project was on determining the interactions between these polymerases and the replicative polymerase and SSB. Whereas there is generally a specific chemical signature on a given protein surface for interaction of SSB, this project has identified likely additional sites of interaction between DNA polymerases and SSB.

During DNA replication, relatively large amounts of single-stranded DNA are produced as the DNA is unwound to allow synthesis of the new DNA strand. This is inherently risky because single-stranded DNA is susceptible to attack by chemicals and enzymes in the cell. The SSB protein is critical for cell survival as it binds to and protects single-stranded DNA. SSB needs to bind well enough to protect the DNA, but not so tightly that it blocks other DNA transactions. This research project determined that free SSB that is not bound to DNA has a role in removing SSB or weakening its binding to SSB, which provides a mechanism by which SSB that is otherwise stably bound can be removed from DNA to allow access to the DNA for replication and repair.

The broader impacts of this project included providing numerous opportunities for professional development of students and faculty. The project included research experiences in the laboratory section of a Chemical Biology course, which is a required course for Chemistry majors. The project also involved high school students, undergraduate students, and graduate students in the research project, which provided them with training in protein chemistry, molecular biology, and computer modeling. The PI was deeply engaged in professional development workshops for new faculty and future faculty, as well as mentoring workshops for students, postdocs, and faculty.
